comments.body: Looks good Oleks.  For consistency need to delete para 8 from Implementation experience Appendix.

```suggestion
9. In cases where the reporting device is the source or destination of a tunnel, the ingress protocol for a packet may differ from the egress protocol (e.g., if IPv4 is tunneled over IPv6).  Some implementations may attribute egress discards to the ingress protocol.
```

pulls.title: Update draft-ietf-opsawg-discardmodel.md
pulls.author: johnevansuk
pulls.body: Added new requirement 11 related to mirrored traffic

comments.body:
```suggestion
11. When traffic is mirrored, the discard metrics MUST account for the original traffic rather than the reflected traffic.
```

```suggestion
12. Traffic to the device control plane has its own class. However, traffic from the device control plane SHOULD be accounted for in the same way as other egress traffic.
```
Please indicate in which case, it is OK to not follow this SHOULD. If there are no such exceptions, then revert this is a MUST
Hi Med - sorry I can't do this one.  In American English it's ok to start a sentence with however, but in British English it never is :)
I will add in the qualification on the SHOULD - thanks!

> Hi Med - sorry I can't do this one. In American English it's ok to start a sentence with however, but in British English it never is :)

I trippled checked this - you're right!

:-)

Unless we have an exception for that SHOULD, you can revert it to MUST
Yes -  will do
Done

comments.body:
```suggestion
12. NoBuffer discards can be realized differently with different memory architectures. Whether a NoBuffer discard is attributed to ingress or egress can differ accordingly.  For successful auto-mitigation, discards due to an egress interface congestion MUST be able to be reported on `egress`, while discards due to device-level congestion (e.g., due to exceeding the device forwarding rate) MUST be able to be `ingress`.
```

reviews.author: boucadair
reviews.body:
as we are fixing nits. Here more :-)

Also, fixes the validation errors due to some references.

comments.body:
```suggestion
: The type or class of discards, which is crucial for selecting the appropriate mitigation. Examples may be:  error discards may require taking faulty components out of service, no-buffer discards may require traffic redistribution, or intended policy discards typically require no automated action.
```

```suggestion
While FEATURE-DISCARD-SCOPE, FEATURE-DISCARD-RATE, and FEATURE-DISCARD-DURATION are implicitly supported by the Interfaces Group MIB {{?RFC2863}} and the YANG Data Model for Interface Management {{?RFC8343}}, FEATURE-DISCARD-CLASS requires a more detailed classification scheme than they define. The Information Model provided in {{infomodel}} defines such a classification scheme to enable automated mapping from loss signals to appropriate mitigation actions.
```

```suggestion
The Information Model is defined using YANG {{!RFC7950}}, with Data Structure Extensions {{!RFC8791}}, allowing the model to remain abstract and decoupled from specific implementations in accordance with {{?RFC3444}}. This abstraction supports different data model implementations, such as YANG or IPFIX {{?RFC7011}}, while ensuring consistency across implementations. Using YANG for the Information Model enables this abstraction, leverages the community's familiarity with its syntax, and ensures lossless translation to the corresponding YANG data model, which is defined in {{datamodel}}.
```

we mix protocols vs. data model  (gNMI/SNMP)

```suggestion
:  These are discards due to buffer exhaustion (that is, congestion related discards). These can be tail-drop discards or due to an active queue management algorithm, such as Random Early Detection) (RED {{RED93}} or Controlled Delay (CoDel) {{?RFC8289}}.
```

```suggestion
This section is modeled after the template described in {{Section 3.7 of ?I-D.ietf-netmod-rfc8407bis}}.
```

